entry.title: Combined summary - One-Shot Replace-By-Fee-Rate
entry.summary:
Peter Todd's recent updates to his Libre Relay fork of Bitcoin introduce a replace-by-fee mechanism that requires at least doubling the fee rate for transaction replacements. This feature relies on a service bit for node compatibility and efficient transaction propagation, currently running on both mainnet and testnet. Although not officially released, the code is open for review and testing with an emphasis on feedback concerning possible exploits in the replace-by-fee-rate code and observations of potential denial-of-service attacks. The update controversially removes limits on OP_Return, with Todd claiming he can already mine oversized OP_Return transactions, suggesting others with Libre Relay nodes might replicate this capability. For further insights or dialogue, Todd is reachable via email, accessible through his website [petertodd.org](https://petertodd.org) after slight modification.
The correspondence also delves into Bitcoin's replace-by-fee rules, specifically addressing concerns raised during a step of an unspecified process. It discusses the contradiction of replacing high fee-rate transactions, which are likely to be mined quickly, with lower fee-rate transactions that defy miner incentives. The inadequacies of BIP-125 Rule 2, which allows combining unconfirmed inputs from different replaced transactions, are highlighted as it may lead to less attractive options for miners. A draft fix proposed on GitHub (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26451) aims to ensure all unconfirmed inputs in a replacement transaction originate from the same initial transaction. While this solution could limit certain economically viable replacements, it would resolve the identified issue. Additionally, permission is sought to use graphics to elucidate the concept in various educational materials, including a post about replace-by-fee-rate.
A critique of the One Shot Replace By Fee Rate (RBFr) proposal identifies potential risks to the Bitcoin network's stability if implemented. An alternative replacement cycle involving two confirmed inputs and five transactions is proposed, which could manipulate the feerate and absolute fee structure, increasing network bandwidth costs. This minimal example suggests larger implications for escalated costs, questioning the safety of the One Shot RBFr deployment. The sender's analysis implies significant unintended consequences for the Bitcoin network if this proposal is adopted without careful consideration.
Furthermore, a blog post explores a new transaction replacement approach in Bitcoin, aiming to improve upon current RBF policy's limitations. The proposed One-Shot Replace-By-Fee-Rate focuses on fee-rate over total fee to avoid transaction pinning attacks and prioritizes transactions likely to be included in the next block. This method addresses vulnerability to pinning attacks by circumventing BIP-125 Rule 3, promoting competition for block space through increased transaction fees. The proposal outlines conditions for transaction replacement, emphasizing fee-rate to position transactions favorably within the mempool. Research backed by Fulgur Ventures concludes that both one-shot and pure replace-by-fee-rate policies can withstand bandwidth exhaustion attacks, potentially making these mechanisms suitable for enhancing the efficiency and security of Bitcoin's network and second-layer protocols.
